questions.question: How does the irrelevance of randomness connect to the big why question of the universe?
So is it possible to for sure know that our universe does not at the fundamental level have randomness?
The question is, what is the analog of hypersonic flow for things about the structure of spacetime?
What is the observer not able to state about this universe of space and time?
Similarly, for intelligence, we know the human definition of intelligence, but what is intelligence abstractly?
What is the sort of factoring of something, what are some other possible ways you could exist, so to speak?
How can it be the case that we can draw these reasonable, it just ended up in this place?
Could there be sort of conscious entities that exist at the level of atoms of space?
So in other words, we don't have to ask the question why does it exist?
Is it possible to encode all, I mean, once we, is there something that isn't what we can represent formally?
What was it which we don't pay any attention to when we're just talking about chemical concentrations?
Is it something more like some network of interactions between these different kinds of immune system cells and so on?
It's kind of this idea of can we express things about the world in computational terms?
And so the question is, can one make a sort of global theory of economics?
And so there's this kind of meta-science question of, given these models, what is the core model?
